description: Curated training pairs for fine-tuning cross-lingual entity matching in early modern scientific texts (1500s-1890s). Additive format: each batch is independently contributed. Append new batches to train on more data.
instructions: To add pairs: append a new batch object to the 'batches' array with a unique batch_id. Do not modify existing batches. To exclude a pair from a previous batch, add it to an 'exclusions' list in your new batch. Positive pairs teach the model that source ↔ target are the same entity. Hard negatives teach it that source ≠ target despite surface similarity.

batches.notes: Initial curation from concordance. Filtered v3 extraction (removed ~20 blocked clusters, transparent cognates, OCR garbage, known bad pairs) + priority-mined pairs from richest cross-lingual clusters. Hand-crafted hard negatives from domain knowledge.

batches.notes: Temporal-conceptual pairs: same concept with different names across time periods. These are the hardest and most valuable matches — the model must learn that early modern terminology maps to modern equivalents despite zero surface similarity. All pairs attested in the actual corpus entity files. Also includes anticipated pairs for likely future book additions (Newton, Harvey, Paracelsus, Vesalius, Lavoisier).

positive_pairs.reasoning: Browne 1646 vernacular → James 1890 medical term. 244 years apart.
Culpeper 1652 English → Latin medical term used across corpus. Both = tuberculosis.
Culpeper 1652 English vernacular → Portuguese/Latin medical term. Both = edema.
Culpeper 1652 folk name → modern medical name. Tuberculosis of the lymph nodes.
Browne 1646 vernacular → medical Latin-derived term. Malaria with 72-hour cycle.
Older English (James 1890 uses both) → modern medical. Same condition.
Culpeper 1652 folk name → 19th-century medical term. Iron deficiency anemia.
Culpeper 1652 (25 mentions) → modern medical. Painful inability to urinate.
Browne/Culpeper Biblical-medical term → Kosmos/Darwin epidemiological concept.
Culpeper 1652 vernacular → modern medical. Same venereal disease.
Browne/Culpeper "Physick" (= healing arts) → modern "medicine". Attested 29x in early books.
Browne/Culpeper pharmaceutical term → modern equivalent. Uncompounded remedies.
Culpeper 1652 spelling → modern. Greek-derived chirurgia = hand-work.
Browne 1646 / Kosmos 1845 → Spencer 1862 / Somerville 1858. The great disciplinary renaming.
Galenic vital fluid → 19th-century physiology. James 1890 uses both, bridging eras.
Same shift. James explicitly glosses animal spirits as "Locke's term for neural processes".
Browne/Culpeper vitalist principle → Kosmos/Somerville/Spencer physical force.
Same shift as above. Culpeper uses Antipathy 9x as therapeutic principle.
Browne 1646 "invisible emanations" → Somerville/Spencer "energy radiation".
Kosmos 1845 (6 mentions) → modern biology term for origin of life from non-living matter.
Spencer 1862 transitional terminology → modern physics. Same law.
Browne 1646 (9 mentions) → Somerville 1858. Alchemical name → modern chemistry.
Browne/Culpeper vernacular → modern element name. Already in batch 1 but adding temporal context.
Browne/Culpeper → Kosmos/Somerville. Oil of vitriol = concentrated sulfuric acid.
Browne 1646 (5x) / Somerville (5x) → element name. Both terms coexist in Somerville.
Somerville 1858 uses both (5x and 9x). Alchemical distillation term → modern.
Kosmos/Somerville/James. Hypothetical heat-substance → recognized as energy transfer.
Browne/Culpeper/Somerville. Medieval mineral name → modern chemical formula.
Browne 1646 (42 mentions! his favorite topic) → Kosmos/Somerville abstract concept.
Browne 1646 (5x) → Kosmos/Somerville. Property of having magnetic poles.
Kosmos/Somerville (13x). Distinguished from "wandering stars" (planets). Now just "stars".
Somerville 1858 captures the particle vs wave debate. Newton's corpuscles → Huygens' waves.
Kosmos/Somerville/Spencer. Named after Galvani → modern concept of biological electricity.
Somerville/Spencer/James. Hypothetical light-carrying medium → eventually abandoned post-Michelson-Morley.
Browne 1646 "mental representations" (Aristotelian) → Darwin 1859 "unit of classification" (191x).
17th century "vegetable" = anything that grows → modern narrowing to edible plants only.
ANTICIPATED for Lavoisier/Priestley texts. Stahl's fire-substance → Lavoisier's element.
ANTICIPATED for Harvey's De Motu Cordis. Harvey's discovery → modern anatomy.
ANTICIPATED for Paracelsus/van Helmont. Alchemical life-principle → vitalist biology.
ANTICIPATED for 18th-century chemistry texts. Bergman's term → modern chemical bonding.

hard_negatives.reasoning: Same word, different meaning! Physick (1650s) = medicine. Physics (1850s) = natural science. The model must NOT collapse these.
Same Latin root (species = appearance/kind), but in early modern texts "species" often meant spices/commodities, not biological taxa.
Galenic bodily fluids (blood, phlegm, choler, melancholy) vs modern "humor" (comedy). Completely different concepts sharing a word.
Aristotelian "element" (earth, water, air, fire) vs post-Lavoisier chemical element (oxygen, hydrogen). Different ontologies.
In Browne/Culpeper, "spirit" = vital essence, subtle bodily fluid. In chemistry, "spirit" = volatile distillate. Related etymology but different referents.
Alchemical "calx" = powdery residue of any calcined metal. Modern "calcium" = specific element. The calx of lead is not calcium.
Galenic humor (yellow bile, associated with anger) vs infectious disease (Vibrio cholerae). Same Greek root, completely different medical concepts.
Early modern "corruption" = humoral imbalance, putrefaction. Modern "infection" = microbial invasion. Related but fundamentally different causal models.

batches.notes: Psychology / philosophy of mind / science of the mind. Cross-temporal English-English pairs spanning Browne/Culpeper (1640s-50s Galenic faculty psychology) through Spencer/James (1860s-90s experimental psychology), plus cross-lingual English-French-German pairs anticipating Wundt and Charcot texts. Focuses on non-obvious matches that a general embedding model would not know.

positive_pairs.reasoning: Culpeper 1652 (32x): a humor/disease caused by black bile excess. Modern: a mood disorder. Same clinical picture, completely different causal model.
Culpeper: excess of cold/dry black bile. Modern: personality trait. The humoral substrate is gone but the phenotype persists.
Culpeper 1652 (2x): hot brain inflammation causing delirium. James 1890 uses "psychosis" (8x). Same acute madness, different frameworks.
Culpeper: disease of the hypochondrium (upper abdomen) causing melancholy. Modern: anxiety about health. Same word, shifted from abdominal disease to mental condition.
Culpeper 1652 (6x): things suffered by the heart (seat of feeling). James 1890 (7x "emotions"): psychological states. "Passion" meant passive experience, not intensity.
Browne 1646 (2x): Aristotelian/Thomistic faculty — anger, daring, hope. Modern: no single term, closest is anger/aggression research.
Browne 1646 (2x): Aristotelian — love, desire, pleasure. Modern: appetitive motivation. The Thomistic faculty division is completely lost.
Browne 1646 (6x): yellow bile humor producing anger/heat. Modern: the temperamental trait survives without the humoral substrate.
Culpeper 1652 (76x!): the organ that filters black bile, seat of melancholy. By 18th century, "spleen" = bad mood. Organ → emotion metonymy.
Culpeper: humoral heaviness of the vital spirits. Modern: psychomotor retardation / fatigue. The "spirits" framework is gone.
Culpeper: vapors rising from the spleen to the brain. 18th-century "the vapours" = female hysteria/anxiety. Same clinical phenomenon, humoral → psychological.
Browne 1646: "conceit" = a mental conception, idea, thought (not vanity). Modern cognate: concept/conception.
Culpeper 1652 (16x): vital/animal/natural spirits as vehicles of sensation and movement. James 1890: nerve-currents (5x), reflex action (6x). Same function, substance → electricity.
Browne 1646: your humoral constitution (hot/cold, wet/dry mix), NOT skin color. Modern: personality temperament. The word "complexion" shifted entirely to appearance.
Culpeper: humoral blockage in the brain. James (4x "cortical lesion"): neuroanatomical damage. Same localization impulse, different causal models.
Locke/Hume philosophical concept → James 1890 (9x + 5x "associationist psychology"): a school of thought James critiques. Term persists but gains institutional weight.
James 1890 uses both (10x / 3x). His own coinage — the metaphor that consciousness flows rather than being composed of discrete atoms.
ANTICIPATED (Wundt). Wundt's central concept. Literally "placing-before" — variously translated as idea, representation, presentation. James discusses Vorstellungen directly.
ANTICIPATED (Wundt). Literally "in-finding" — the raw sensory datum before interpretation. James (50x "sensation") debates Wundt's Empfindung concept.
ANTICIPATED (Wundt). Literally "being-aware-ness." Central to German psychology. James (314x) and Spencer (122x) both engage with the German tradition.
ANTICIPATED (Wundt/Kant). Literally "looking-at" — Kant's pure intuition of space/time. English "intuition" loses the visual/perceptual core of the German.
ANTICIPATED (Wundt). Literally "one-image-power" — the faculty of forming mental images. Zero surface similarity to English.
ANTICIPATED (Wundt). Literally "irritation/provocation." Fundamental to Wundt's psychophysics. James (24x "stimulus"). Completely non-obvious mapping.
ANTICIPATED (Fechner/Wundt). Literally "doorstep." Fechner's absolute and difference thresholds. Zero surface similarity.
ANTICIPATED (Wundt). Literally "hampering." James (6x "inhibition"). Key concept in reflex arc theory. Non-obvious.
ANTICIPATED (Wundt). Literally "muscle-feeling" — proprioception/kinesthesia. James discusses this extensively. Completely non-obvious mapping.
ANTICIPATED (Wundt). Literally "sense-deception." James discusses illusions extensively. The German compound is poetically transparent but unrecognizable to English.
ANTICIPATED (Wundt). German Seelenkunde ("soul-knowledge") = psychology. Seele ranges across soul/psyche/mind in a way English can't capture in one word.
ANTICIPATED (Wundt). In German psychology, Lust/Unlust is the fundamental dimension of feeling (pleasure/displeasure). English "lust" has narrowed to sexual desire — a false friend.
ANTICIPATED (Wundt, later Freud). Instinctual drive/urge. James uses "instinct" (various, 10+ mentions). The German Trieb is broader than English "drive."
ANTICIPATED (Wundt). Literally "will-choice" — voluntary/free action. James (34x "will"). The German emphasizes the choice aspect.
ANTICIPATED (Charcot). Literally "mental alienation" — the self estranged from reason. James (4x "insanity"). French psychiatric tradition's foundational term.
ANTICIPATED (Charcot/Janet). Literally "fixed idea" — an idea that dominates consciousness and resists displacement. Central to French theories of hysteria.
ANTICIPATED (Charcot/Janet/Ribot). Literally "doubling of personality." James discusses this at length. The French term is far more vivid than clinical "dissociation."
ANTICIPATED (Charcot). Charcot's second stage of grande hystérie. James (10x "hypnotic trance", 4x "somnambulism"). French clinical → English experimental terminology.
ANTICIPATED (Charcot). French clinical nosology — functional nervous disease without structural lesion. James (8x "psychosis") uses the competing German-influenced term.
ANTICIPATED (Charcot/Falret). Literally "circular madness" — mood cycling. The English term (Kraepelin) emphasizes the poles, the French the cycle.
ANTICIPATED (Charcot). The hysterical patient's striking unconcern about severe symptoms. Still used untranslated in English psychiatry.
ANTICIPATED (Claude Bernard, relevant to Charcot's physiology). Literally "interior milieu" → homeostasis (Cannon). Foundational concept in physiology.
ANTICIPATED (Mesmer/Charcot). The hypnotist-subject bond. English borrows "rapport" but strips the magnetic/therapeutic specificity it has in French clinical tradition.
ANTICIPATED (Wundt). Untranslatable — encompasses mind, temperament, feeling-nature, emotional disposition. No single English word covers it. James struggles with this concept.
ANTICIPATED (Wundt/Hegel). Covers mind, spirit, intellect, ghost. Geisteswissenschaften = "sciences of the mind" = humanities. English cognate "ghost" has narrowed to supernatural.
ANTICIPATED (Charcot/philosophical). Locke's "understanding" → French "entendement" → back to English with different philosophical loading. The round-trip changes the concept.

hard_negatives.reasoning: Sensation (psychophysical datum) vs sentimentality (literary/cultural movement). Same root empfinden but entirely different domains.
Mental representation (psychology) vs artistic representation/performance (aesthetics). Both = "representation" but in completely different senses.
Psychological automatism (unconscious behavior) vs automaton (mechanical device). Related metaphorically but different referents.
Stimulus (psychology) vs rice (the grain). Identical pronunciation in German, completely unrelated.
Neurological condition (Charcot) vs logical fallacy (rhetoric). Both from Greek hystera (womb/later) but different fields.
Madness (French psychiatric) vs book format (printing). Surface-similar, unrelated.
Soul/psyche (German psychology) vs See/Seele (lake/sea in some dialects). Homographic confusion.
Therapeutic bond (Mesmer/Charcot) vs to report/bring back (general French). Same root but the clinical meaning is specialized and non-obvious.
Humoral constitution/temperament (Browne 1646) vs physical appearance (modern English). The word completely shifted meaning — a model must NOT treat them as equivalent.
Wundt/James: active creative synthesis vs passive sensory intake. Apperception is NOT just fancy perception — it involves the unity of consciousness acting on raw data.

batches.notes: Expanded psychology/mind science + temporal science pairs. Anticipates additions of Wundt, Charcot, Galton, Helmholtz, Janet, Agassiz. Covers: (1) cross-temporal English mind/psychology terminology shifts, (2) English-German pairs for psychophysics/experimental psychology, (3) English-French pairs for clinical neurology/dissociation, (4) additional temporal science concept shifts, (5) 25 hard negatives targeting confusable terms in this domain.

Agassiz glaciology; transported boulders

hard_negatives.note: hysteria (psychological) ≠ hysteresis (physics loop phenomenon)
psychiatrist ≠ foreigner; same Latin root alienus
nerve exhaustion/fatigue ≠ nerve pain; both neuro- but different conditions
skull-based brain mapping ≠ seasonal biological cycles; one letter difference
psychological therapy (moral=mental) ≠ ethics; "moral" has different meaning
Mesmerism/hypnosis ≠ physical magnetism; totally different phenomena
psychological dissociation (Janet) ≠ physical breakdown/decay
attention (psychology) ≠ Enlightenment (historical period); similar Auf- prefix
hysterical rigidity ≠ chemical catalysis; similar French words
hypnotic trance state ≠ mere drowsiness; both sleep-related
personality type (humoral theory) ≠ heat measure; etymological siblings
Wundt cultural psychology ≠ folklore studies; both Volk- but different disciplines
automatic physiological response ≠ philosophical contemplation; same Latin root
Hallerian cellular excitability property ≠ inflammation/annoyance
medical homesickness ≠ nerve pain; both -algia but different roots
visual after-image ≠ role model; both -bild compounds
Ice Age ≠ detail/particularity; similar initial syllables
lack of will (Janet) ≠ ending of institution; similar spelling
hypnosis technique ≠ art/behavioral style; similar -ism ending
obsolete heat substance theory ≠ modern energy unit; etymological but conceptually different
luminiferous medium (physics) ≠ diethyl ether (anesthetic chemical)
Leibniz kinetic energy ≠ vital force; both Latin vis + adjective
theoretical fire-substance ≠ real chemical element; both Greek phlog-/phos- (fire/light)
emanation/radiation ≠ crystalline deposit on surface; similar Latin ef- prefix
Morel psychiatric decline ≠ biological regrowth; opposite processes, similar morphology

batches.notes: Wider historical science scope. Anticipates Margaret Cavendish, Erasmus Darwin, 18th c. proto-psychology (Hartley, Condillac, Bonnet), proto-anthropology (Blumenbach, Buffon, Lafitau). Covers: (1) 17th c. natural philosophy terminology (Cavendish era), (2) Erasmus Darwin proto-evolutionary/medical terms, (3) 18th c. associationist psychology, (4) early anthropological terminology, (5) historical English disease names → modern equivalents, (6) 18th c. science concept shifts.

positive_pairs.note: Cavendish vitalist materialism → modern physics/biology concept
17th c. faculty psychology: rational spirits govern thought
17th c.: spirits that carry sense-impressions → neural pathways
Standard 17th c. philosophical term (Hobbes, Cavendish) → modern
17th c. English plural form → modern
Della Porta/Bacon tradition: manipulating hidden natural causes
Pre-Newtonian: hidden causal powers in matter (legitimate science, not supernatural)
E. Darwin Zoonomia: the living filament as proto-gene concept
Pre-Darwinian term (E. Darwin, Lamarck) → C. Darwin
E. Darwin: involuntary responses to stimuli → modern reflex concept
E. Darwin: motions caused by sensation → sensory neuroscience
E. Darwin/Hartley: capacity to form associations → learning theory
E. Darwin medical: pathological unresponsiveness → modern psychiatry
E. Darwin: absence/suppression of irritability → inhibitory neuroscience
E. Darwin: fiber-based movement theory → modern physiology
Life from nonlife: ancient theory → modern origin-of-life research
Hartley 1749: nerve vibrations as basis of sensation → modern neuroscience
Hartley: miniature vibrations encoding past experience → engram concept
Hartley/Hume/Locke foundational principle → modern learning theory
Condillac: all thought is transformed sensation → information processing
Condillac/French tradition → modern memory retrieval
Bonnet 18th c. French neurology → modern cell biology (pre-neuron doctrine)
Reid Scottish philosophy: innate perceptual faculty (NOT colloquial meaning)
Blumenbach nisus formativus: force directing biological development
Buffon: deviation from archetype species (NOT Morel psychiatric decline)
Buffon taxonomic: sub-specific variation → modern population biology
18th c. French ethnographic term (Lafitau, Rousseau) → modern
Lafitau comparative ethnography: customs/manners of peoples
German skull-measurement → standard anthropological English term
19th c. German anthropological: natural-peoples (vs Kulturvölker)
Cervical lymphadenitis; believed curable by royal touch
Prison-associated epidemic disease → identified pathogen
Intermittent fever, extremely common in early modern texts
From Greek kynanche (dog-strangling) → modern clinical term
Rye fungus poisoning; named for monastic hospital order
Involuntary movement disorder; patron saint association
Extremely common early modern complaint → urological diagnosis
Fluid retention/swelling; from Greek hydrops
Iron-deficiency anemia in young women; 16th-19th c. diagnosis
Descriptive term → specific pathological diagnosis
Humoral description (putrefaction) → blood infection
lights=lungs in early modern English; respiratory distress in children
Static metaphysical hierarchy (Lovejoy) → dynamic evolutionary branching
18th c. general term for bodily functions → modern discipline name
French 18th c. → English modern discipline

hard_negatives.note: imagination (philosophical faculty, Hobbes/Cavendish) ≠ ornamental/decorative; identical word, radically different meanings
vital fluid in nerves (Galenic physiology) ≠ alcoholic beverages; critical early modern disambiguation
biological reproduction (E. Darwin, preformationism debates) ≠ age cohort; same word, different technical meanings
Reid faculty of direct perception ≠ everyday practical wisdom; philosophical vs colloquial
having sensory capacity (17th c. natural philosophy) ≠ emotionally fragile (modern colloquial)
hidden natural forces (legitimate pre-Newtonian science) ≠ supernatural mystical practice
psychological mechanism (Hartley/Hume) ≠ social organization/club
E. Darwin hereditary thread (proto-gene) ≠ incandescent lamp filament; same word
species change (pre-Darwinian evolution) ≠ alchemical transmutation (lead→gold)
Blumenbach formative biological drive ≠ education/cultural cultivation; Bildung has very different valence
Buffon racial variation from archetype ≠ Morel hereditary psychiatric decline; same root, different century, different technical meaning
indigenous peoples (ethnographic) ≠ rescue operation; similar French words
Buffon taxonomic sub-specific variation ≠ entertainment variety show
medical catatonia/psychiatric unresponsiveness ≠ animal hibernation dormancy; related but distinct
physiology (bodily functions) ≠ livestock farming; both "animal" but completely different domains
17th c. atoms ≠ body structure; similar appearance, unrelated
metaphysical hierarchy ≠ physical/nuclear cascade; both "chain" but different domains
life from nonlife ≠ self-ignition; both "spontaneous" but biology vs chemistry
nerve fibers (neurons) ≠ muscle fibers; both "fibres" in French anatomy
edema (fluid retention) ≠ sleepy; similar sound, unrelated
